<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 507, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 912, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 806, 613]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> An object of mass \(1.0 \text{kg}\) is at rest on Earth. An identical object is at rest on a planet with a gravitational field strength of twice that on Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 757, 135]]<|/det|> Which row correctly compares the object on the planet to the object on Earth? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 145, 576, 291]]<|/det|>
its weightits acceleration when the same horizontal force is applied
Adoubleequal to that on Earth
Bdoublehalf that on Earth
Chalfequal to that on Earth
Dhalfhalf that on Earth

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 501, 571, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 561, 485, 580]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 591, 490, 610]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 109, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 781, 91]]<|/det|> To calculate the power produced by a force, the size of the force must be known. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 559, 120]]<|/det|> What else needs to be known to calculate the power? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 129, 693, 278]]<|/det|>
the distance that the force moves the objectthe time for which the force acts on the object
A\(\checkmark\)\(\checkmark\)
B\(\checkmark\)\(\boldsymbol {x}\)

key
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 203, 751, 222]]<|/det|>
\(\checkmark\) = needed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 230, 779, 248]]<|/det|> x = not needed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 304, 106, 323]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 620, 323]]<|/det|> A student calculates the pressure due to the liquid at point X. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 330, 588, 426]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 437, 456]]<|/det|> The student takes four measurements. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 468, 386, 486]]<|/det|> 1 density of the liquid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 494, 428, 512]]<|/det|> 2 temperature of the liquid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 520, 608, 539]]<|/det|> 3 depth of point X below the surface of the liquid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 546, 433, 564]]<|/det|> 4 surface area of the liquid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 707, 594]]<|/det|> Which measurements must the student use in her pressure calculation? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 604, 134, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 604, 170, 622]]<|/det|> 3 and 4 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 604, 303, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 604, 386, 622]]<|/det|> 1 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 604, 473, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 604, 504, 622]]<|/det|> 1 and 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 604, 636, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 604, 720, 622]]<|/det|> 2 and 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 650, 107, 668]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 463, 668]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a mercury barometer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 680, 665, 698]]<|/det|> Which height is used as a measurement of atmospheric pressure? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 705, 702, 928]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 818, 91]]<|/det|>
A student splashes water on to her face. Here are three statements about the effects.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 101, 529, 120]]<|/det|>
P The water uses energy to evaporate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 127, 564, 146]]<|/det|>
Q The water gains energy from the student.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 153, 470, 171]]<|/det|>
R The face of the student cools.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 371, 201]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 138, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 751, 229]]<|/det|>
P and Q only B P and R only C Q and R only D P, Q and R

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 256, 107, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 255, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Equal volumes of solids and liquids experience different changes of volume when they are heated through the same temperature range.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 301, 346, 320]]<|/det|>
What is the reason for this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 330, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
The average increase in separation of the particles in a liquid is greater than the average increase in separation of those in a solid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 371, 133, 389]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 371, 920, 404]]<|/det|>
The average increase in separation of the particles in a liquid is less than the average increase in separation of those in a solid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 412, 133, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 412, 636, 431]]<|/det|>
The particles in liquids expand by less than those in solids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 439, 133, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 439, 645, 457]]<|/det|>
The particles in liquids expand by more than those in solids.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 483, 106, 502]]<|/det|>

protonsneutrons
A90144

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 408, 106, 427]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 455, 427]]<|/det|> Which statement about \(\gamma\) -rays is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 437, 133, 455]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 437, 608, 455]]<|/det|> They are deflected by both electric and magnetic fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 133, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 463, 667, 481]]<|/det|> They are deflected by magnetic fields but not by electric fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 133, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 489, 667, 508]]<|/det|> They are deflected by electric fields but not by magnetic fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 133, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 516, 707, 534]]<|/det|> They are not deflected either by electric fields or by magnetic fields. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 560, 107, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 551, 579]]<|/det|> Which equation represents the \(\beta\) -decay of lead-209? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 592, 133, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 591, 401, 616]]<|/det|> \(^{209}_{82}\mathrm{Pb} + \mathrm{}^{0}_{-1}\mathrm{e} \rightarrow \mathrm{}^{209}_{83}\mathrm{Bi}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 648]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 626, 401, 651]]<|/det|> \(^{209}_{82}\mathrm{Pb} + \mathrm{}^{0}_{-1}\mathrm{e} \rightarrow \mathrm{}^{209}_{81}\mathrm{Tl}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 133, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 662, 401, 687]]<|/det|> \(^{209}_{82}\mathrm{Pb} \rightarrow \mathrm{}^{209}_{83}\mathrm{Bi} + \mathrm{}^{0}_{-1}\mathrm{e}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 133, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 700, 401, 725]]<|/det|> \(^{209}_{82}\mathrm{Pb} \rightarrow \mathrm{}^{209}_{81}\mathrm{Tl} + \mathrm{}^{0}_{-1}\mathrm{e}\)
